text:
hi there, i really like the strategy builder in <https://github.com/liampauling/flumine/blob/master/flumine/strategy/strategy.py|flumine> and i’m giving a go now!

i’m wondering if there’s a way to configure it to *not use* the streaming API and run the framework on a fixed interval instead?

alternatively, is there a way to configure the stream to trigger the fetch every minute?

elements.text: hi there, i really like the strategy builder in
flumine

and i’m giving a go now!

i’m wondering if there’s a way to configure it to
not use

the streaming API and run the framework on a fixed interval instead?

alternatively, is there a way to configure the stream to trigger the fetch every minute?

text: Use the conflate_ms parameter to set the frequency of streaming updates

elements.text: Use the conflate_ms parameter to set the frequency of streaming updates

text:
yeah use conflate and you can set the `streaming_timeout` to 60 so that you can an update every 60s <https://liampauling.github.io/flumine/advanced/#parameters|regardless>

```strategy = ExampleStrategy(
    market_filter=streaming_market_filter(
        event_type_ids=["7"],
        country_codes=["GB"],
        market_types=["WIN"],
    ),
    conflate=5000,  # 5s
    streaming_timeout=60,  # 60s (should probably change this to match conflate)
) ```

elements.text: yeah use conflate and you can set the
streaming_timeout
to 60 so that you can an update every 60s
regardless

strategy = ExampleStrategy(
    market_filter=streaming_market_filter(
        event_type_ids=["7"],
        country_codes=["GB"],
        market_types=["WIN"],
    ),
    conflate=5000,  # 5s
    streaming_timeout=60,  # 60s (should probably change this to match conflate)
)

text: Hey guys, finally getting to start looking at football. I need historic and live time series of epoch time, goal state, cards, possession state, ball position (for example dangerous attack), free kick or penalty status etc. I don’t want to hit betfairs public end points, these are critical feeds and I am happy to pay for this data. Is Betgenius the only game in town for Premier League / Bundesliga? What kind of bill is one looking at for this?

elements.text: Hey guys, finally getting to start looking at football. I need historic and live time series of epoch time, goal state, cards, possession state, ball position (for example dangerous attack), free kick or penalty status etc. I don’t want to hit betfairs public end points, these are critical feeds and I am happy to pay for this data. Is Betgenius the only game in town for Premier League / Bundesliga? What kind of bill is one looking at for this?

text: Decent data is going to be very expensive

elements.text: Decent data is going to be very expensive

text: Like £100K a year expensive?

elements.text: Like £100K a year expensive?

text: Or even more?

elements.text: Or even more?

text: I think Opta will be the most detailed

elements.text: I think Opta will be the most detailed

text: Probably depends how many leagues you want, so easier to think about price per match

elements.text: Probably depends how many leagues you want, so easier to think about price per match

text: I see, does Opta provide live stream as well or will it be delayed for live (as Betgenius may have exclusive rights for premier league)?

elements.text: I see, does Opta provide live stream as well or will it be delayed for live (as Betgenius may have exclusive rights for premier league)?

text: if you don't want detailed x/y but only the # of dangerous attacks -> sportmonks advanced data

elements.text: if you don't want detailed x/y but only the # of dangerous attacks -> sportmonks advanced data

text: if you need play-by-play data historical you can go to one of the providers, but expect to pay 2k /league on a yearly basis

elements.text: if you need play-by-play data historical you can go to one of the providers, but expect to pay 2k /league on a yearly basis

text: £2K a year per league is totally acceptable

elements.text: £2K a year per league is totally acceptable

text: live is where it gets tricky

elements.text: live is where it gets tricky

text: Opta, Sportradar and Statsbomb are the only 3 i know of that do live data delivery (wyscout and instat don't)

elements.text: Opta, Sportradar and Statsbomb are the only 3 i know of that do live data delivery (wyscout and instat don't)

text: Opta is super-expensive, ~30$/match

elements.text: Opta is super-expensive, ~30$/match

text: Statsbomb too, they start at 10K/year per league

elements.text: Statsbomb too, they start at 10K/year per league

text: Spotradar never asked, but their data is lower coverage

elements.text: Spotradar never asked, but their data is lower coverage

text: and lower quality

elements.text: and lower quality

text: so depends a lot on which leagues you are looking at. sportradar has a uhm.. reasonably easy to access data endpoint if you look around

elements.text: so depends a lot on which leagues you are looking at. sportradar has a uhm.. reasonably easy to access data endpoint if you look around

text: What does it mean that Betgenius is “exclusive” content provider for Premier League and Bundesliga? That means all other providers must wait N seconds in live to update content from stadiums?

elements.text: What does it mean that Betgenius is “exclusive” content provider for Premier League and Bundesliga? That means all other providers must wait N seconds in live to update content from stadiums?

attachments.title: Genius Sports launches lawsuit against Sportradar
attachments.text: Genius Sports has filed a lawsuit against rival provider Sportradar in the UK High Court over the data firms’ ongoing legal dispute, according to a report by Sportico. In May 2019, the Genius Sports subsidiary was

text: Though tbh I've always been quite skeptical. Is there a consistent methodology used for quantifying whether an attack is dangerous or not

elements.text: Though tbh I've always been quite skeptical. Is there a consistent methodology used for quantifying whether an attack is dangerous or not

text: no, everybody has their own, and that's why you need to make sure your live data and historical data are from the same provider :stuck_out_tongue:

text: What’s the delay on in football data, that’s the problem. Is it just someone watching the game on sky?

text: Thanks for the input <@U0128E7BEHW> While the public endpoint is good, I am hesitant to use it. Complexity in terms of data capture, one has to build the data archive over time and it feels that one is always one step away from evoking betfair’s ire. Sometimes throwing money at the problem is a good enough solution (so betgenius can enjoy their monopolistic rent collection).

elements.text: Thanks for the input

While the public endpoint is good, I am hesitant to use it. Complexity in terms of data capture, one has to build the data archive over time and it feels that one is always one step away from evoking betfair’s ire. Sometimes throwing money at the problem is a good enough solution (so betgenius can enjoy their monopolistic rent collection).

text: What is betfair matching sort order for all orders received between two matching cycles? are cancels prioritised over new orders?

text: First come first serve, more or less. Cancels are not prioritised other than not being subject to the bet delay

text: <@U01NJ85MP7F> has joined the channel

hey guys, I've been playing with using bwlw to parse the historical data sets. am I right in my understanding that, although the historic data files include runner and market name, because the stream API doesn't include the names bflw doesn't support pulling the names out of the historic files? very happy to be corrected if my understanding is wrong here, otherwise keen to hear if anyone has a work around or if there are plans to support it in the package in the future?

elements.text: hey guys, I've been playing with using bwlw to parse the historical data sets. am I right in my understanding that, although the historic data files include runner and market name, because the stream API doesn't include the names bflw doesn't support pulling the names out of the historic files? very happy to be corrected if my understanding is wrong here, otherwise keen to hear if anyone has a work around or if there are plans to support it in the package in the future?

text: They should be there, market name is in the definition

elements.text: They should be there, market name is in the definition
